G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, the Court may make such orders as are necessary to protect the welfare of the child, including designating a primary physical custodian and restructuring parenting time to reflect the circumstances of the parties and the child’s best interests.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.proposition: The paramount concern of the Court in any matter affecting custody or parenting time is the best interests of the child. See, e.g., Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840–41 (2003); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1996).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the “best interests of the child” standard as the governing principle in custody determinations and cites earlier Massachusetts cases stating that the best interests of the children remain the paramount concern. Although the quoted language about paramount concern comes from Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, Custody of Kali reaffirms that the best-interests standard is the controlling test in custody and visitation matters and applies it to resolve the dispute. This directly supports the proposition that the court’s paramount concern in custody/parenting time matters is the child’s best interests.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.proposition: The paramount concern of the Court in any matter affecting custody or parenting time is the best interests of the child. See, e.g., Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840–41 (2003); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1996).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly applies and discusses the ‘best interests of the child’ standard, but it does not clearly state, in so many words, that the best interests of the child are the ‘paramount’ concern in all custody or parenting‑time matters. The focus of the decision is on requiring explicit findings about domestic violence and its impact on the child within that best‑interests framework, rather than articulating the broad, general principle expressed in the proposition. Therefore, while consistent with the proposition, it is not strong authority for that exact formulation.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.relevant_excerpt: We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below “fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.” … There are significant reported psychological problems in children who witness domestic violence… Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 899–900 (1981) (rescript)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A material change in circumstances justifying modification may include changes in a parent’s physical or mental health, changes in a parent’s capacity to care for the child safely, or other developments that materially impact the child’s welfare. See, e.g., Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 845–46; Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 899–900 (1981) (rescript); Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191–92 (1998).
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss modification standards or material changes in circumstances, nor does it mention parental physical/mental health or capacity changes as a basis for modification. Instead, it addresses an initial custody award and reiterates the general best-interests-of-the-child standard and the need to consider all relevant factors, without specifying the types of changes listed in the proposition. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191\.proposition: A material change in circumstances justifying modification may include changes in a parent’s physical or mental health, changes in a parent’s capacity to care for the child safely, or other developments that materially impact the child’s welfare. See, e.g., Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 845–46; Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 899–900 (1981) (rescript); Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191–92 (1998).
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191\.support_reasoning: Rosenberg v. Merida is a modification case, but its discussion of modification standards in the quoted pages concerns child support and legal custody generally, without identifying what types of changed circumstances (such as a parent’s physical or mental health or caregiving capacity) can constitute the requisite material change. The opinion only briefly notes that the parties’ inability to communicate might be a material and substantial change, and it ultimately vacates the custody modification for lack of findings. It therefore does not meaningfully support the specific proposition that material changes include changes in parental health, caregiving capacity, or other developments affecting the child’s welfare.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191\.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ … The only finding contained in the modification judgment is that ‘the parties are unable to communicate with one another.’ Although we express no opinion in this regard, that finding, if supported by the record, might be minimally sufficient to warrant a conclusion that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties had occurred.”}

Hernandez v. Branciforte, 55 Mass. App..raw_text: Hernandez v. Branciforte, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 212, 219–20 (2002)
Hernandez v. Branciforte, 55 Mass. App..proposition: The Court has broad discretion to modify physical custody and parenting schedules to protect a child’s physical safety and emotional well‑being when changed circumstances warrant such relief. See Hernandez v. Branciforte, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 212, 219–20 (2002); Adoption of Garret, 92 Mass. App. Ct. 664, 671–72 (2018).
Hernandez v. Branciforte, 55 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the Probate and Family Court’s authority to modify physical custody upon a material and substantial change in circumstances, guided by the child’s best interests, including the child’s relationships and overall welfare. The Appeals Court affirms a transfer of sole physical custody to the father, emphasizing that the judge weighed all relevant factors, including the child’s need for a meaningful relationship with both parents and the impact of the mother’s conduct on his welfare. Although it does not use the exact phrase "broad discretion," it clearly recognizes and upholds the trial judge’s wide latitude to modify custody and the parenting arrangement to protect the child’s best interests when circumstances change.
Hernandez v. Branciforte, 55 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “The judge recognized that a transfer of custody from one parent to another must be based on some material and substantial change in circumstances since the divorce, … and that the change must be of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle, namely, whether the transfer is in the best interests of the child… The judge’s additional findings concerning the father’s parenting skills, close relationship with his son, and the preparations that he had made to enroll Maximillian in school upon his return from Italy need not be repeated. We are satisfied that the judge considered all relevant factors in weighing the best interests of Maximillian with respect to physical custody.”

Adoption of Garret, 92 Mass. App. Ct. 66.raw_text: Adoption of Garret, 92 Mass. App. Ct. 664, 671–72 (2018)
Adoption of Garret, 92 Mass. App. Ct. 66.proposition: The Court has broad discretion to modify physical custody and parenting schedules to protect a child’s physical safety and emotional well‑being when changed circumstances warrant such relief. See Hernandez v. Branciforte, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 212, 219–20 (2002); Adoption of Garret, 92 Mass. App. Ct. 664, 671–72 (2018).
Adoption of Garret, 92 Mass. App. Ct. 66.support_reasoning: Adoption of Garret is not a physical custody–modification case and does not discuss the Probate and Family Court’s broad discretion to modify physical custody or parenting schedules upon changed circumstances. Instead, it is a Juvenile Court care‑and‑protection/termination case focused on parental fitness, termination of parental rights, post‑termination custody determinations, and visitation (including de facto parent, biological parent, and sibling visitation). While it affirms that custody and visitation decisions are guided by the child’s best interests and reviewed for abuse of discretion, it does not articulate or apply the specific principle of broad discretion to modify existing physical custody and parenting schedules upon changed circumstances, so it is not a good authority for the proposition as framed.
Adoption of Garret, 92 Mass. App. Ct. 66.relevant_excerpt: “In making a custody determination, the ‘driving factor’ is the best interests of the child. … A judge’s determination as to what is in the best interests of the child will not be overturned on appeal unless it amounts to an abuse of discretion or a clear error of law. … The judge did not abuse her discretion in approving DCF’s plan to place Garret in the custody of his maternal grandmother; the judge considered the relevant factors and her decision did not ‘fall[ ] outside the range of reasonable alternatives.’”

Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 61.proposition: In evaluating the child’s best interests, the Court may consider, among other things, the child’s age and developmental needs; the physical and mental health of each parent; each parent’s capacity to provide for the child’s needs; the degree of stability each household can offer; and whether the custodial arrangement will place unreasonable emotional or caretaking burdens on the child. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 848–49; Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 618–19 (1986); Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575, 580–81 (2007).
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 61.support_reasoning: This opinion applies a general ‘best interests/unfitness’ framework and discusses stability, safety, and prognostic evidence, but it does not articulate or enumerate the specific best‑interests factors listed in the proposition (age and developmental needs, physical and mental health of each parent, each parent’s capacity, degree of stability in each household, or unreasonable emotional/caretaking burdens on the child). The court focuses on parental unfitness, history of abuse, violence, and the need for a stable, safe environment, without setting out a multi‑factor test or expressly authorizing consideration of those particular factors. Thus, while conceptually related, it does not clearly serve as authority for the detailed proposition stated.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 61.relevant_excerpt: “The judge adopted the opinion of the psychologist at Children’s Hospital Medical Center, that the son needed an emotionally stable home environment unavailable to him in the home of his parents. … The court is permitted to assess prognostic evidence derived from prior patterns of parental neglect or misconduct in determining future fitness and the likelihood of harm to the child. … The judge could properly have concluded that committing the children to the custody of the department would be in their best interest.”

Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.raw_text: Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575, 580–81 (2007)
Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.proposition: In evaluating the child’s best interests, the Court may consider, among other things, the child’s age and developmental needs; the physical and mental health of each parent; each parent’s capacity to provide for the child’s needs; the degree of stability each household can offer; and whether the custodial arrangement will place unreasonable emotional or caretaking burdens on the child. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 848–49; Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 618–19 (1986); Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575, 580–81 (2007).
Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: Guardianship of Estelle discusses the relationship between parental fitness and the child’s best interests, especially in the context of a child’s bonding with current caretakers and the potential trauma of a custody transfer. However, it does not set out or apply a multi‑factor ‘best interests’ test involving the child’s age and developmental needs, each parent’s physical and mental health, each parent’s caregiving capacity, household stability, or emotional/caretaking burdens on the child in the manner described in the proposition. Those elements come from other Massachusetts custody cases (such as Custody of Kali and Custody of Two Minors), not from this opinion, so citing Estelle for that specific factor list overstates what it holds.
Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: “Because we do not deal with a subject that is susceptible to ‘mathematical precision,’ criteria of necessity must be stated in general terms, and the principles may be difficult to apply in individual cases. … At a minimum, the fitness of a particular parent cannot be judged without a consideration of that parent’s willingness and ability to care for the child, as well as the effect on a child of being placed in the custody of that parent. One who is fit to parent in some circumstances may not be fit if the circumstances are otherwise.” (70 Mass. App. Ct. at 580–81.)

Adoption of Carla, 416 Mass. 510, 514\u2.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that exposing a child to unsafe conditions or placing inappropriate caretaking responsibilities on a child can be inconsistent with the child’s best interests. See Adoption of Carla, 416 Mass. 510, 514–16 (1993) (emphasizing the need for a safe environment and freedom from undue adult burdens); Adoption of Mary, 414 Mass. 705, 711–12 (1993) (considering the impact of parental limitations on the child’s welfare).
Adoption of Carla, 416 Mass. 510, 514\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames the ultimate question as whether the mother is currently unfit to further the welfare and best interests of the child, and then affirms a termination judgment based on extensive evidence that Carla was subjected to abuse and a dangerous, violent environment in the mother’s household. The court recounts evidence of serious physical abuse, weapons in the home, the child’s trauma and psychological damage, and expert opinions that returning Carla to that environment would be dangerous and not in her best interests. While the court does not articulate a separate doctrinal rule about ‘placing inappropriate caretaking responsibilities’ on a child, it clearly recognizes that exposing a child to unsafe, abusive conditions is inconsistent with the child’s best interests and supports termination on that basis.
Adoption of Carla, 416 Mass. 510, 514\u2.relevant_excerpt: “In a G. L. c. 210, § 3, proceeding, a judge must find by clear and convincing evidence that a parent is presently unfit to provide for the welfare and best interests of the child in order to grant the petition.… There were three reports…relating to Jeremy…for medical neglect…[and] bruises… There were court records and testimony…that Sally’s present husband, Frank, had been indicted on seven counts of assault and battery…on Jeremy, and that Sally had been indicted… The therapist…testified that she believed there had occurred physical, emotional, and sexual abuse while Carla lived with Sally, and that it would be dangerous for Carla to be returned to that environment….”}

Adoption of Mary, 414 Mass. 705, 711\u20.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that exposing a child to unsafe conditions or placing inappropriate caretaking responsibilities on a child can be inconsistent with the child’s best interests. See Adoption of Carla, 416 Mass. 510, 514–16 (1993) (emphasizing the need for a safe environment and freedom from undue adult burdens); Adoption of Mary, 414 Mass. 705, 711–12 (1993) (considering the impact of parental limitations on the child’s welfare).
Adoption of Mary, 414 Mass. 705, 711\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on parental unfitness and best interests in terms of severe physical and sexual abuse, neglect, and the mother’s failure to protect the children, not on exposing a child to generally unsafe conditions or imposing inappropriate caretaking burdens in the broader sense stated in the proposition. While the case clearly ties parental conduct and the child’s need for safety to the best‑interests analysis, it does not specifically discuss placing inappropriate caretaking responsibilities on a child or elaborate on "unsafe conditions" beyond abuse and failure to protect from an abusive partner. Thus it only indirectly relates to, and does not clearly establish, the specific legal principle claimed.
Adoption of Mary, 414 Mass. 705, 711\u20.relevant_excerpt: “Parental unfitness must be determined by taking into consideration a parent’s character, temperament, conduct, and capacity to provide for the child in the same context with the child’s particular needs, affections, and age… The judge made detailed findings that the long history of physical and sexual abuse has been profoundly detrimental to the needs and best interests of both children. He found that J.B. had participated in the physical abuse and neglect of the children and was unable to protect her children from future abuse.”

Adoption of Gregory, 434 Mass. 117, 125\.proposition: While disability in and of itself does not disqualify a parent from having custody or parenting time, the Court must carefully examine the practical impact of a parent’s condition on the child’s safety and welfare. See Adoption of Gregory, 434 Mass. 117, 125–26 (2001); see also Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225–26 (1998) (courts must evaluate actual ability to care for the child, not stereotypes or assumptions).
Adoption of Gregory, 434 Mass. 117, 125\.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly rejects any per se rule that mental illness, cognitive limitation, or disability alone establishes unfitness, and instead requires evaluation of the parent’s actual capacity to meet this particular child’s needs. The court emphasizes that the central inquiry is whether the parent can provide at least a minimally adequate level of care in light of the child’s specific vulnerabilities and special needs, and it upholds termination based on the demonstrated practical impact of the parents’ conditions on the child’s safety and welfare, not on disability status itself.
Adoption of Gregory, 434 Mass. 117, 125\.relevant_excerpt: “Despite the parents’ special needs or limited capabilities, ‘the child is entitled to at least a minimum level of parental care.’… See Adoption of Nicole, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 259, 262 (1996) (‘the central judgment’ concerns whether parent ‘has the capacity to act as a fit parent’).… While the judge acknowledged that ‘the mere presence of these problems does not imply’ parental unfitness, she made concrete findings… that the parents could not sufficiently overcome these problems to be able to provide minimally adequate parenting to a child with significant special needs….”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.proposition: While disability in and of itself does not disqualify a parent from having custody or parenting time, the Court must carefully examine the practical impact of a parent’s condition on the child’s safety and welfare. See Adoption of Gregory, 434 Mass. 117, 125–26 (2001); see also Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225–26 (1998) (courts must evaluate actual ability to care for the child, not stereotypes or assumptions).
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.support_reasoning: This opinion does not concern a disabled parent or any disability-based limitation on custody or parenting time. The discussion focuses on comparing two alternative adoptive placements (a foster mother versus an aunt) under a best-interests analysis, with no mention of disability stereotypes or a requirement to assess the practical impact of a parent’s condition. Accordingly, citing Adoption of Hugo for the stated disability-related proposition is inaccurate; that principle comes from other cases, not this one.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.relevant_excerpt: "Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’"
